message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and medical history suggest gout, which is caused by the accumulation of urate crystals in the joints. A drug that has a reversible inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis, such as NSAIDs, can reduce inflammation and pain associated with gout attacks. Option (B) is incorrect because it refers to aspirin, which has an irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase. Option (C) is incorrect because selective inhibitors of cyclooxygenase-2 are not indicated for the treatment of acute gout attacks. Option (D) is incorrect because drugs that irreversibly inhibit xanthine oxidase, such as allopurinol, are used for the prevention of gout attacks, not for the treatment of acute attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and medical history suggest gout, which is a result of excess uric acid production or decreased excretion. Reversible inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis is the mechanism of action of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen, which can relieve pain and inflammation associated with gout.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Gout, which is treated with drugs that inhibit prostaglandin synthesis. Options B and C are incorrect because they refer to irreversible inhibition of COX enzymes, which can cause other adverse effects. Option D refers to drugs used to treat hyperuricemia but not acute gout attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with gout, which is caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in joints. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the first-line therapy for acute gout attacks and they work by reversibly inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis. Option (B) describes aspirin, which irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase. Option (C) describes selective COX-2 inhibitors, which are not recommended for gout treatment. Option (D) describes allopurinol, which irreversibly inhibits xanthine oxidase and is used for long-term management of gout, not acute attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and medical history suggest gout, and drug treatments for gout aim to reduce inflammation and pain. Reversible inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis, such as with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), is a commonly used treatment for gout. Cyclooxygenase inhibitors and xanthine oxidase inhibitors are also used in treating gout, but NSAIDs are the first-line drug of choice for acute gout attacks. Selective inhibition of cyclooxygenase-2 is a newer type of NSAID, but there is no evidence that it is more effective than traditional NSAIDs in treating gout.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest gout, which is caused by the deposition of uric acid crystals in the joints. Anti-inflammatory drugs such as NSAIDs, which inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, are the first-line treatment for acute gout attacks. Irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase would be more appropriate for preventing platelet aggregation or managing chronic inflammation. Selective inhibition of cyclooxygenase-2 would also be inappropriate for acute gout attacks. Irreversible inhibition of xanthine oxidase is used for long-term management of gout, not for acute attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest gout, and the drug that is commonly used to treat gout is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), which work by reversible inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. Options B, C, and D are all incorrect as they do not target gout specifically.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and medical history suggest gout, which is characterized by inflammation and pain in the joints. Among the options, only reversible inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis can help reduce inflammation and relieve pain associated with gout. Options B and C refer to NSAIDs, which can also be used for pain relief but are not the most appropriate first-line treatment for gout. Option D refers to allopurinol, which is used for long-term management of gout but is not appropriate for acute attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the patient’s history of sporadic painful episodes over the past 3 years and her alcohol consumption, suggest gout. Reversible inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis can help alleviate the pain and swelling associated with gout. The other options do not target gout specifically.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest gout, and the presence of a nodule over the right elbow suggests chronic tophaceous gout. Reversible inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis is the mechanism of action of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), which are often used to treat acute gout attacks.
